DOC.HEAD: Winter Retains Icy Grip On Eastern States
Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT number of cities with record lows to 56, sted 57.
DOC.TEXT: The persistent cold wave gave Florida record lows Sunday, and stirred up a snowstorm that piled snow in 8-foot drifts in the Carolinas, but a slight warming trend moved onto the Plains Record or record-tying lows were reported for 56 cities from Texas to Florida and north to New England. Temperatures dipped below zero as far south as Tennessee and freezing temperatures were reported as far south as southern Florida, where Miami cooled to a record 31 degrees. The Florida Keys was the only place in the eastern half of the country without freezing temperatures from late Saturday into Sunday morning. Sunday's official low for the Lower 48 states was 27 degrees below zero at Houlton, Maine, with unofficial lows of 33 below zero reported in the West Virginia mountain valley communities of Glady and Cheat Bridge. Wind blew at 40 to 50 mph along the Outer Banks of North Carolina, causing considerable blowing and drifting snow and knocking down power lines. In Hyde County, on the coast of the mainland, the wind created snow drifts up to 8 feet high. Snowfall totals in eastern South Carolina ranged up to 14 inches at Myrtle Beach, with 8 inches at Charleston. Light snow dusted northern Florida, but much of the state got ice on roads and crops. Light snow also dusted the southeastern corner of New England. In the central part of the nation, temperatures rose rapidly. The temperature hit 40 degrees at Chamberlain, S.D., and Minneapolis warmed into the 20s after nearly five straight days below zero. Kansas City, Mo., had a December record of 16 below zero Saturday, but highs in the 30s and 40s were predicted for Monday in the region. Temperatures even remained above freezing overnight across parts of the northern Plains. Sunday's low of 33 at Dickinson, N.D., was 66 degrees higher than the city's morning low on Friday. Clouds and light snow accompanied the warmer weather from Kansas and Arkansas to Minnesota and Michigan.
